citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
In the clinic building, there is a bottle of medication labeled, “Micky ¼ Benazepril” with no other information. The facility
stated that this medication is being given to an adult male capuchin named “Micky” as long-term treatment following a
stroke. When asked for the original bottle that the medication came from, the facility presented a prescription bottle for a
different animal that contained 10mg Benazepril tablets which had an expiration date of 9/1/2023. Upon reviewing the
discharge paperwork and prescription issued for “Micky”, it was discovered that his prescription is for ¼ tablet of 5mg
Benazepril. At the time of inspection, “Micky” is getting twice the dose as originally prescribed. The medication he is
receiving is also expired.
Administering the incorrect dose of medication can have serious consequences for the animal, including unintended side
effects and worsened outcomes. The use of expired medications is not considered to be a safe or appropriate method to
prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries since the expected results cannot be guaranteed. The facility
must give medications as directed by the attending veterinarian. The facility must use appropriate methods to prevent,
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.

There is an open jar of peanut butter in the kitchen that expired on 10/4/2023. This peanut butter is used by care staff for
various nonhuman primates at the facility.
Palatability and nutritive value cannot be guaranteed in expired food. Any food fed by the facility must be clean,
wholesome, and palatable to the animals. It must be of sufficient quantity and have sufficient nutritive value to maintain a
healthful condition and weight range of the animals and to meet its normal daily nutritional requirements. The facility
discarded the jar of peanut butter during the inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
GWENDALYN MAGINNIS, Nonhuman Primate Field Specialist n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
In the clinic building, there is a bottle of medication labeled, “Micky ¼ Benazepril” with no other information. The facility 
stated that this medication is being given to an adult male capuchin named “Micky” as long-term treatment following a 
stroke. When asked for the original bottle that the medication came from, the facility presented a prescription bottle for a 
different animal that contained 10mg Benazepril tablets which had an expiration date of 9/1/2023. Upon reviewing the 
discharge paperwork and prescription issued for “Micky”, it was discovered that his prescription is for ¼ tablet of 5mg 
Benazepril. At the time of inspection, “Micky” is getting twice the dose as originally prescribed. The medication he is 
receiving is also expired. 
Administering the incorrect dose of medication can have serious consequences for the animal, including unintended side 
effects and worsened outcomes. The use of expired medications is not considered to be a safe or appropriate method to 
prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries since the expected results cannot be guaranteed. The facility 
must give medications as directed by the attending veterinarian. The facility must use appropriate methods to prevent, 
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. 
3.82(a)  Repeat
   
Feeding. 
There is an open jar of peanut butter in the kitchen that expired on 10/4/2023. This peanut butter is used by care staff for 
various nonhuman primates at the facility.  
Palatability and nutritive value cannot be guaranteed in expired food. Any food fed by the facility must be clean, 
wholesome, and palatable to the animals. It must be of sufficient quantity and have sufficient nutritive value to maintain a 
healthful condition and weight range of the animals and to meet its normal daily nutritional requirements. The facility 
discarded the jar of peanut butter during the inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

Additional Inspectors: 
GWENDALYN MAGINNIS, Nonhuman Primate Field Specialist n
